_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Smith Dairy Wayne Division
1590 N. W. 11th Street
Richmond, IN  47375

NAICS #: 31152

Process: 

Smith Dairy is a milk and dairy processing plant that uses anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant for the purpose of cooling product during the process operation and for product storage. The refrigeration system at the Smith Dairy Wayne Division is a single stage, closed loop system with a total system charge of 16, 939 pounds of ammonia.

Chemical Hazards of Anhydrous Ammonia:

Permissible Exposure Limit -- 25 PPM for 8 hours
Short Term Exposure Limit  --  35 PPM for 15 minutes
Immediately Dangerous to Life or Health (IDLH)  --  300 PPM
Inhalation Hazard  --  1,000 PPM
Skin Absorption Hazard  --  10,000 PPM
Lower Explosive Limit (LEL)  --  16%
Upper Explosive Limit (UEL)  --  25%
EPA Toxic Endpoint  --  200 PPM

Worst-case Scenario Data:

The worst-case release, toxic endpoint was determined using the RMPComp software provided by EPA. The worst-case scenario is based on the following criteria:

Vessel Designation  --  Pump Recirculator 
Vessel Size  --  60" x 10' 0"
Maximum Vessel Quantity  --  5,550 pounds
Amount Released  --  5,550 pounds
Duration of Release  --  10 minutes
Release Rate  --  555 lbs/min
Wind Speed  --  1.5 meter/sec
Atmospheric Stability  --  F
Topography  --  Rural
Passive Mitigation  --  Enclosure
Distance to toxic Endpoint  --  1.0 mile
Affected Population  --  1,858
Public Receptors  --  One Hospital, Residences

The maximum level is this vessel is controlled by the operation of a liquid line solenoid valve which is opened and closed by the vessels liquid-level probe. Should this control fail, high level cutouts will shut the system down stopping the flow of liquid to the vessel.

Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies:

Smith Dairy has established an in-house emergency response team to quickly respond to and handle releases of Anhydrous Ammonia. The established steps include initial training under the OSHA regulation 29 CFR 1910.120 'HAZWOPER'. The facility has also established annual retraining for all personnel that are on the HAZMAT Team as well as periodic spill drills and plant wide evacuation drills to assure all employees are prepared in the event of an emergency. Smith Dairy has also coordinated response efforts with the local Fire Department personnel and community Emergency Management Agency. These established plans and procedures shall be periodically reviewed to assure that they are current and up to date.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

Smith Dairy Wayne Division has not only complied with the EPA Risk Management Program but also the OSHA Process Safety Management regulation to assure that the Ammonia Refrigeration System is well maintained and employees are properly trained and periodically retrained to assure they are kept up to date on any changes and new operations that may effect them. In addition, to maintain the mechanical integrity and safety of this process, Smith Dairy practices the following industry codes and standards:
 ASME Boiler & Pressure Valve Codes
 ANSI B31.3 Piping Code
 IIAR industry guideline for safety and good engineering practices
 NFPA guidelines for fire protection equipment
  
Through regular audits, training, maintenance, testing and inspection programs of the ammonia refrigeration system at Smith Dairy, the facility has established a history of safe operation and that community emergency action plans are current and training with

community services is done for a safe response in the event of an accidental release.

Five Year Accident History:
None to report. 

Emergency Response Program:

Public Emergency Responders:

City Fire Department
City Law Enforcement
County Sheriffs Department
City and County Ambulance Service

Special Resources Available From Facility:

Smith Dairy Wayne Division has trained the refrigeration operators and selected production personnel in Hazardous Waste Operation and Emergency Response '29 CFR 1910.120. The trained personnel will access each release situation and determine the appropriate emergency response to initiate. This could be by simply tightening a packing nut or flange bolt or initiating a system shut down. This facility has also established written operating procedures for the ammonia refrigeration system and have included in those procedures the Emergency Shutdown and isolation of equipment in the event of a release. Smith Dairy has purchased Level A Chemical Suites, Self Contained Breathing Apparatus and other appropriate equipment to support the in-house HAZMAT team. This team will coordinate their efforts with the outside emergency services to assure the safety of all.
